TrcFtcLib.ftclib

Class FtcMotorActuator

  • java.lang.Object
    • TrcFtcLib.ftclib.FtcMotorActuator

  • public class FtcMotorActuator
extends java.lang.Object
    This class implements a platform dependent motor actuator. A motor actuator consists of a DC motor, a lower limit switch and an optional upper limit switch. It creates all the necessary components for a PID controlled actuator which includes a PID controller and a PID controlled actuator.

    • Nested Class Summary

      static class  FtcMotorActuator.Parameters
      This class contains all the parameters related to the motor actuator.

      • zeroCalibrate

        public void zeroCalibrate(double calPower)
        This method starts the zero calibration process by operating the motor with calibration power moving it towards the lower limit switch. When the lower limit switch is activated, the position sensor is reset and the motor stops.
        Parameters:
        calPower - specifies the motor power for zero calibration.

      • zeroCalibrate

        public void zeroCalibrate()
        This method starts the zero calibration process by operating the motor with calibration power moving it towards the lower limit switch. When the lower limit switch is activated, the position sensor is reset and the motor stops.

      • setManualOverride

        public void setManualOverride(boolean enabled)
        This method enables/disables manual override on the motor actuator. In normal mode, the movement of the actuator is PID controlled so it can slow down when it is close to the lower or upper position limits. It also enables soft upper limit if there is no upper limit switch. In manual override mode, the actuator is no longer PID controlled so the speed of the actuator movement is completely controlled by the caller. However, manual override mode will still respect the physical limit switches and will not allow motor movement to pass the limit switches. This means the actuator can bump into the limit switches full speed in manual override mode. Therefore, it is the operator's responsibility to pay attention to the actuator position. Manual override mode is very useful when the actuator is not properly zero calibrated. For example, if the actuator is in some mid position when the robot is started, the robot will think that position is the zero position and will not allow the actuator to go below it. In this situation, you either have to start a zero calibration or use manual override mode to force the actuator to move towards the lower limit switch. Manual override also allows the actuator to go pass the upper soft limit. This is useful if the robot thinks the actuator is already at the upper limit but physically it can still move a little bit more.
        Parameters:
        enabled - specifies true for enabling manual override mode, false to disable.

      • cancel

        public void cancel()
        This method cancels a previous active PID motor operation.

      • setPower

        public void setPower(double power)
        This method moves the actuator at the given power level. However, if the actuator is close to the limits and manual override mode is not active, the power will be reduced by the PID controller.
        Parameters:
        power - specifies the power level to move the actuator.

      • setPosition

        public void setPosition(double delay,
                        double target,
                        boolean holdPosition,
                        TrcEvent event,
                        double timeout)
        This method starts moving the actuator to the specified position. Generally, when PID operation has reached target, event will be notified and PID operation will end. However, if holdTarget is true, PID operation cannot end because it needs to keep monitoring the position and maintaining it. In this case, it will just notify the event and continue on. The caller is responsible for stopping the PID operation by calling cancel() when done with holding position.
        Parameters:
        delay - specifies delay time in seconds before setting position, can be zero if no delay.
        target - specifies the target position to set the actuator.
        holdPosition - specifies true to hold position after PID operation is completed.
        event - specifies the event to be signal when the actuator reaches the specified position.
        timeout - specifies the maximum timeout for the actuator movement. If the actuator does not reach target within timeout time, the event will be signaled so autonomous state machine will not be hung if for some reason the actuator never reaches target.

      • setPosition

        public void setPosition(double target,
                        boolean holdPosition,
                        TrcEvent event,
                        double timeout)
        This method starts moving the actuator to the specified position. Generally, when PID operation has reached target, event will be notified and PID operation will end. However, if holdTarget is true, PID operation cannot end because it needs to keep monitoring the position and maintaining it. In this case, it will just notify the event and continue on. The caller is responsible for stopping the PID operation by calling cancel() when done with holding position.
        Parameters:
        target - specifies the target position to set the actuator.
        holdPosition - specifies true to hold position after PID operation is completed.
        event - specifies the event to be signal when the actuator reaches the specified position.
        timeout - specifies the maximum timeout for the actuator movement. If the actuator does not reach target within timeout time, the event will be signaled so autonomous state machine will not be hung if for some reason the actuator never reaches target.

      • setPosition

        public void setPosition(double delay,
                        double target,
                        TrcEvent event)
        This method starts moving the actuator to the specified position. The actuator will maintain the target position after target is reached.
        Parameters:
        delay - specifies delay time in seconds before setting position, can be zero if no delay.
        target - specifies the target position to set the actuator.
        event - specifies the event to notify when done.
